conclusion: Determine the volume V_0 of the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak between the chambers.
Identify given variables: Total initial volume of each chamber V, Initial pressure p, Initial temperature T, Mass of the diaphragm m, Height of the cylinder 2H, x = mgH/pV.
Assumptions: The process is quasi-static, so the system is in equilibrium at all stages. The temperature of the gas remains constant as the process is slow and the setup is insulated.
When the piston moves up, the pressure in the lower chamber increases to p + Δp due to the weight of the diaphragm.
The force due to the diaphragm is mg, which causes an additional pressure Δp = mg/A, where A is the cross-sectional area of the cylinder.
Using the ideal gas law for the lower chamber: pV = nRT.
For the lower chamber when the pressure increases: (p + Δp)V_0 = nRT.
Initially, the total volume of both chambers is 2V.
Let the increase in volume of the lower chamber be ΔV, so the volume of the upper chamber is V - ΔV.
When the gas starts to leak, the condition becomes pV = (p + Δp)V_0.
Rearrange to find V_0: V_0 = pV/(p + Δp).
Δp = mg/A and recall that A = V/H.
Given x = mgH/pV, we have Δp = xp.
Thus, V_0 = pV/(p + xp) = V/(1 + x).
The volume of the lower chamber when the gas starts to leak is V_0 = V/(1 + x).
